data.test_name: Some Basic Concepts of Chemistry Test - 3

1.q_string: Which of the following statements about a compound is incorrect?
q_option: A molecule of a compound has atoms of different elements.
A compound retains the physical properties of its constituent elements.
A compound cannot be separated into its constituent elements by physical methods of separation.
The ratio of atoms of different elements in a compound is fixed.

1.q_string: \(10 \mathrm{~dm}^3\) of \(N_2\) gas and \(10 \mathrm{~dm}^3\) of gas \(X\) at the same temperature contain the same number of molecules. The gas \(X\) is:
The number of molecules in \(4.25 \mathrm{~g}\) of \(\mathrm{NH}_3\) is:

Two containers \(\mathrm{P}\) and \(\mathrm{Q}\) of equal volume ( 1 litre each) contain \(6 \mathrm{~g}\) of \(\mathrm{O}_2\) and \(\mathrm{SO}_2\), respectively, at \(300 \mathrm{~K}\) and \(1 ~atm\). Which of the following statements is correct?
q_option: The number of moles in \(\mathrm{P}\) is less than that in \(\mathrm{Q}\).
The number of moles in \(\mathrm{Q}\) is less than that in \(\mathrm{P}\).
Both \(\mathrm{P}\) and \(\mathrm{Q}\) have the same number of moles.

1.q_string: A compound contains only carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. Combustion of \(10.68 \mathrm{~mg}\) of the compound yields \(16.01 \mathrm{~mg}\) of \(\mathrm{CO}_2\) and \(4.37 \mathrm{~mg}\) of \(\mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{O}\). The molar mass of the compound is \(176.1 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{~mol}\). What are the empirical formula of the compound?
Molarity will decrease when we ________ temperature.
Which of the following relations is correct?
q_option: Mass of 1 mole of carbon atoms = mass of 1 g of hydrogen atoms
6.022 x 1023 atoms of carbon = 12 u of carbon
6.022 x 1023 atoms of carbon = 12 g of carbon
Mass of 1 mole of hydrogen atom = mass of 6.022 x 1023 atoms of carbon

1.q_string: The number of oxygen atoms in \(4.4 \mathrm{~gm} \) of \(\mathrm{CO}_2\) is:
The density of water at room temperature is \(1.0 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{ml}\). How many molecules are there in a drop of water if its volume is \(0.05 \mathrm{ml}\)?
At room temperature, the volume of a drop of water is \(0.0018 \mathrm{ml}\). The number of water molecules present in it is:

A \(2.0 \mathrm{~g}\) mixture of \(\mathrm{Na}_2 \mathrm{CO}_3\) and \(\mathrm{NaHCO}_3\) suffered a loss of \(0.12 \mathrm{~g}\) on heating. The percentage of \(\mathrm{Na}_2 \mathrm{CO}_3\) in the mixture was:
How much copper can be obtained from \(100 \mathrm{~g}\) of copper sulphate \(\left(\mathrm{CuSO}_4\right)\)?
The amount of carbon dioxide that could be produced when 2 moles of carbon are burnt in 16 g of dioxygen is:
The simplest formula of a compound which contains \(85.6 \% \mathrm{~C}\) and \(14.4 \% \mathrm{~H}\) by mass is:

9 volumes of a gaseous mixture contain an organic compound and oxygen sufficient for its combustion. Burning the compound yielded 4 volumes of \(\mathrm{CO}_2, 6\) volumes of \(\mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{O}\) and 2 volumes of \(\mathrm{N}_2\), find the molecular formula of the compound?

\(0.9 \mathrm{~g}\) of a compound of mol. wt. 90 and containing only \(\mathrm{C}, \mathrm{H}\) and \(\mathrm{O}\) is exploded with \(224 \mathrm{ml}\) of oxygen. After cooling, the volume was \(560 \mathrm{ml}\), and on passing through \(\mathrm{KOH}\) solution, the remaining volume is \(112 \mathrm~{ml}\). If all volumes were measured at STP, the molecular formula of the liquid compound is
\(100 \mathrm{~mL}\) of \(1 \mathrm{~N} \mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{SO}_4\) is mixed with \(100 \mathrm{~mL}\) of a \(1 \mathrm{~M} \mathrm{~NaOH}\) solution. The resulting solution will be:

A sample of hard water is found to contain \(40 \mathrm{mg}\) of \(\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\) ions per litre. The amount of washing shoda \(\left(\mathrm{Na}_2 \mathrm{CO}_3\right)\) required to soften \(5.0\) L of the sample would be:
If the density of methanol is \(0.793 \mathrm{~kg}/ \mathrm{L}\), what is its volume needed for making \(2.5 \mathrm{~L}\) of its \(0.25 \mathrm{M}\) solution?
Which of the following is not a postulate of Dalton's atomic theory?
q_option: Atoms are not created or destroyed in chemical change.
Different elements have atoms of different masses.
Atoms combine in simple whole number ratios to form compounds.
Atoms of a single element can have different masses.

1.q_string: One mole is the amount of a substance that contains as many particles or entities as there are atoms in:
A given compound always contains exactly the same proportion of elements by weight. This law is stated by
Avogadro's constant is the number of entities ( viz. atoms , molecules or ions) present in ___________ mole of a substance.
An empirical formula represents the simplest:
q_option: Whole number ratio of various atoms present in a compound
Whole number ratio of the  elements present in a compound
Ratio of masses of various elements  present in a compound
Average fractional ratio of various atoms present in a compound

1.q_string: Molecular formula represents:
q_option: The exact number of different types of atoms present in a molecule of a compound
Whole number ratio of different types of atoms present in a molecule of a compound
Average fractional ratio of various atoms present in a compound
Ratio of masses of various atoms present in a compound

1.q_string: According to the law of conservation of mass, a balanced chemical equation:
q_option: The same number of protons of each element on both sides of the equation
The same number of electrons of each element on both sides of the equation
The same ratio of atoms of each element on both sides of the equation
The same number of  atoms of each element on both sides of the equation

1.q_string: Molarity is defined as:
q_option: The number of moles of the solvent in 1 litre of the solution
The number of moles of the solute in 1 m3 of the solution
The number of grams of the solute in 1 litre of the solution
The number of moles of the solute in 1 litre of the solution

1.q_string: The calculation of masses or, (sometimes volumes also) of the reactants and the products involved in a chemical reaction is called:

What is the concentration of sugar \(\left(\mathrm{C}_{12} \mathrm{H}_{22} \mathrm{O}_{11}\right)\) in \(\mathrm{mol}/\mathrm{L}\) if its \(\mathrm{2 0} \mathrm{g}\) are dissolved in enough water to make a final volume up to \(2 \mathrm{L}\)?

What will be the mass of sodium acetate \(\left(\mathrm{CH}_3 \mathrm{COONa}\right)\) required to make \(500 \mathrm{~mL}\) of \(0.375\) molar aqueous solution. Molar mass of sodium acetate is \(82.0245 \mathrm{~g}/\mathrm{mol}\).
